awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Fluid Polyamorphism: Theory, Experiment and Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, supports a collaboration between scientists and engineers at the University of Maryland at College Park, Arizona State University, Boston University, and Princeton University. The collaborative team employs theoretical, computational, and experimental methods to investigate the different types of molecular structures that can occur in liquids. The molecules within a liquid, while not as ordered as they would be in a solid crystal, may still form distinguishable types of structures.  This phenomenon, known as polyamorphism, has been predicted to occur in water at sub-freezing temperatures and high pressures.  The team is employing experimental techniques such as calorimetry (to measure the flow of heat into and out of samples as they undergo phase changes), infrared spectroscopy (to characterize the molecular vibrations in the system), and computational tools (molecular dynamics simulations) to characterize polyamorphic phases in water and other liquids.  In addition to gaining fundamental insights into the nature of matter, the results of this investigation may have impacts in fields such as glass technology, cryobiology, and atmospheric science.  The graduate students involved in this project are gaining experience in both experimental and computational chemistry,  They benefit from personnel exchanges among the different participating institutions.  The broader impacts of the project may include development of computer hardware based on silicon alternatives, better pharmaceutical formulations, new routes to low-temperature tissue preservation, computational models for high school students, and more accurate weather predictions based on an improved understanding of cloud microphysics.

This project involves the development and verification of a generic thermodynamic approach to describe polyamorphism in single-component substances. The unifying concept is that of equilibrium interconversion between competing molecular or supramolecular structures. Simulations involve studies of chirality-driven, liquid-liquid phase separations, critical behaviors and finite-size scaling under deeply supercooled conditions, and the interplay between crystallization, fluid phase separation, and fluid structural relaxation. Calorimetry, optical microscopy, dynamic light scattering, infrared and Raman spectroscopies, and transmission electron microscopy provide complementary experimental characterization on polyamorphic systems, including non-crystallizing aqueous solutions. The two-state thermodynamic formalism provides a unifying theoretical perspective. The broader impacts of the project may include development of computer hardware based on silicon alternatives, better pharmaceutical formulations, new routes to low-temperature tissue preservation, computational models for high school students, and more accurate weather prediction through improved understanding of cloud microphysics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Typically, pure substances exhibit only one gaseous and one liquid state, while their solid state may exist in various crystalline forms. The latter phenomenon is well known as "polymorphism of solids"). Amorphous, alternative to crystalline, structure lacks the translational (solid crystals) or orientational (liquid crystals) order. This structure is a characteristic of liquids. Finding multiple amorphous states of a single component substance is unusual and commonly viewed as exotic. Yet, this phenomenon, known as "liquid polyamorphism", has been discovered in various substances, such as sulfur, phosphorous, liquid carbon, cerium, and superhigh-pressure hydrogen, and predicted to exist in selenium, tellurium, silicon, silica, and, most notably, in supercooled water. In these substances in addition to the liquid-gas coexistence, scientists have also observed (in experimental studies or by simulations) different liquid phases. The transitions between liquid phases may be terminated by liquid-liquid critical points.

It was hypothesized that a generic cause for liquid polyamorphism could be equilibrium interconversion between alternative molecular forms or supramolecular structures in a single-component fluid. We have verified this hypothesis through theoretical and computational studies of fluids containing two interconverting molecular species. Interconversion of species changes the composition (an independent variable) to a fraction of interconversion, a function of pressure and temperature, thus making the system to be thermodynamically equivalent to a single-component one. If the interconverting species "dislike" each other (as the molecules of water and oil), the fluid may exhibit liquid polyamorphism separating into different liquid phases.

We have proposed and investigated a minimal model for this phenomenon. Starting with a compressible binary lattice model exhibiting liquid-gas transitions and liquid-liquid demixing, we allow interconversion of the two species, turning the system into a single-component fluid with the possibility of multiple liquid-gas and liquid-liquid critical points, depending on the interplay between the energies of molecular interactions and the energy and entropy of interconversion. The model provides a unified theoretical framework to describe liquid polyamorphism in supercooled water and a variety of polyamorphic liquids with waterlike anomalies.

We also investigated the effects of molecular interconversion on phase formation. Phase separation of substances may become drastically different if the species, whether individual molecules or supramolecular aggregates, interconvert. Interconversion may destroy or spatially restrict phase formation. Phase segregation is caused by mutual diffusion of species toward the formation of coexisting states separated by an interface. The formation of the interface is energetically unfavorable; however, it is inevitable since the number of molecules of each species must be conserved. Interconversion breaks the conservation law and enables one of the alternative phases to grow at the expense of the other. This phenomenon is known as "phase amplification." We have developed a phenomenological theory of phase amplification and confirmed the theory by computational studies (Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics simulations) of three microscopic models, a hybrid Ising/lattice-gas model, a chiral model exhibiting demixing of enantiomers, and a model in which the interconversion of species is caused by collision with external particles. All these models demonstrate phase amplification if the interconversion rate is fast enough for breaking the conservation of species. However, if in addition to equilibrium interconversion, there exists a nonequilibrium source of energy forcing the alternative species to interconvert to equal amounts, an interplay between the "natural" (equilibrium) interconversion, "forced" (nonequilibrium) interconversion, and mutual diffusion generates a striking phenomenon of the formation of steady-state dissipative structures (striped of bicontinuous). Such microphase separation is one of the simplest examples of dissipative structures in condensed matter. Possible manifestations of this energy source in nature could include a nonequilibrium environment of living cells or a flux of photons.

Impacts of our studies are broad and interdisciplinary. The results benefit basic science through better understanding the unusual phase behavior of substances with molecular or supramolecular interconversion. Still, after 50 years of intense research efforts, the famous 1972 statement by Felix Franks,  "of all known liquids, water is probably the most studied and least understood", remains relevant. As a result of our studies, we are now convinced that water's polyamorphism at supercooling conditions is indeed caused by interconversion of hydrogen-bonded structures. The results obtained from the proposed research can be used in new product and process designs, wherever the anomalous properties of supercooled water and aqueous solutions can be utilized. One especially pertinent engineering application is the development of international standards for the correlation of thermophysical properties of supercooled water, a task assigned by the International Association for the Properties of Water and Steam.

The results of the project will have a significant educational impact by contributing to the contents of a textbook for science and engineering majors ("Introduction to Mesoscopic Thermodynamics"), which awaits publication in 2024.
